Class BinaryTree

java.lang.Object
  BinaryTree

public class BinaryTree
extends java.lang.Object

Define a binary tree and its supporting methods. This class also handles the necessary tree traversals for drawing the nodes.

Version:
1.0 2005-OCT-21
Author:
Rob Bauer

Returns:

getDepth

public int getDepth()
Recursively calculate the depth of a tree. Take the current tree and find the depth of its right and left parts. Which ever one is greater, return it plus one. Continue dividing the tree up until the root node is null.

Returns:
the depth

getNodeCount

public int getNodeCount()
Recursively calculate the node count. Traverse both sides of the tree and return the number of nodes found.

Returns:
node count found for the left and right sides of the tree.

postorderTraversal

public java.lang.String postorderTraversal()
Perform a post order traversal of the given binary tree. This method sets up for recursion. This method also is a friendly interface to the traverse function. Mode #2 is for post order.

Returns:
String containing the node data in post order.

inorderTraversal

public java.lang.String inorderTraversal()
Perform an in order traversal of the given binary tree. This method sets up for recursion. This method also is a friendly interface to the traverse function. Mode #1 is for post order.

Returns:
String containing the node data in order.

preorderTraversal

public java.lang.String preorderTraversal()
Perform a pre-order traversal of the given binary tree. This method sets up for recursion. This method also is a friendly interface to the traverse function. Mode #0 is for post order.

Returns:
String containing the node data in pre-order.

traverseOrder

public java.lang.String traverseOrder(int mode)
Start the traversal process. Before traversing the tree, the string buffer needs to be setup.

Parameters:
mode - Given traversal to perform. 0 = pre-order, 1 = in-order, 2 = post-order
Returns:
String containing the traversed tree's node data in the order as specified by mode.

traverse

private void traverse(int mode,
                      BinaryNode node,
                      java.lang.StringBuffer sBuffer)
Traverse a binary tree based on the root node given, the traversal mode, and the buffer to store the data in.

Parameters:
mode - Given traversal to perform. 0 = pre-order, 1 = in-order, 2 = post-order
node - BinaryNode containing the root node to traverse
sBuffer - StringBuffer to store the node data in.

drawTree

public void drawTree(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                     int left,
                     int bottom,
                     int boxsize,
                     int x_spacing,
                     int y_spacing)
Draw the binary tree graphically. The tree is first traversed in-order to determine the nodes' points. Once found, the tree is traversed again using pre-order to draw the nodes and the connecting lines. This was done to wiggle around the problem of drawing the lines behind the nodes. A better solution would be to use multiple JPanels and draw the nodes on one and then lines on a second one. Then place the node panel above the line panel. This would mean the tree is only traversed once instead of twice, but would introduce added complexity.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to paint with
left - The left (x-axis) value to start drawing from
bottom - The bottom (y-axis) value to starting drawing from
boxsize - The box size to use - this is the width. For circles, this is the diameter.
x_spacing - The horizontal spacing to use between nodes.
y_spacing - The vertical spacing to use between nodes.

drawNodeLines

private void drawNodeLines(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                           BinaryNode node,
                           BinaryNode lastNode,
                           int boxsize)
Draw a node and lines to its children using recursion. The traversal used is pre-order.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to paint with
node - BinaryNode to start drawing from
lastNode - The last node drawn. This typically will be the node's parent
boxsize - The box size to use to draw the node.

labelNode

private void labelNode(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                       BinaryNode node,
                       java.awt.Point center,
                       int boxsize)
Label a node. If the node's data is a '-' or '|' then draw lines. Otherwise, draw the node's data. This method does not validate the node's data. It should be a valid char value.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to paint with.
node - BinaryNode to label
center - Point specifying where to draw the label
boxsize - The box size. This is used to determine how large to draw the vertical and horizontal lines

drawFilledSquare

private void drawFilledSquare(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                              java.awt.Point center,
                              int boxsize)
Draw a filled square. This is usually a leaf node (if everything is working ok!).

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to paint on
center - Point specifying where to draw the node
boxsize - The box size to use

drawFilledCircle

private void drawFilledCircle(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                              java.awt.Point center,
                              int boxsize)
Draw a filled circle. This is usually a root node (if I'm traversing the tree correctly!).

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to paint with
center - Point specifying where to draw the node
boxsize - The box size to use

nodes2Draw

private int nodes2Draw(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                       int left,
                       int top,
                       int boxsize,
                       int x_spacing,
                       int y_spacing,
                       int depth,
                       int count,
                       BinaryNode node)
Traverse the tree in-order and determine the nodes and their center points so we can draw the nodes. This method gets the recursion rolling. The method for drawing the nodes was modelled after the one specified in our Data Structures and Algorithms in Java book on page 302. For each node, we need to identify its count in the traversal and its depth in the tree. Knowing these two facts allows us to figure out where to draw the node. To make it look pretty, the spacing information is included. This spacing determines how to stretch the tree out (or shrink it) to fit the given window. This also allows for the tree to resize when the window is resized.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to draw with
left - Left value to start drawing from
top - Top value to start drawing from
boxsize - Box size to draw
x_spacing - horizontal spacing to use
y_spacing - vertical spacing to use
depth - depth of the tree calculated
count - node count of the tree
node - current BinaryNode to process
Returns:
count found for the given tree

locateNode

private int locateNode(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                       int left,
                       int top,
                       int boxsize,
                       int x_spacing,
                       int y_spacing,
                       int depth,
                       int count,
                       BinaryNode node)
Calculate the node's location based on the given parameters and the position of the node in the tree. Assign the point location to the node and increment the node counter.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to draw with
left - Left value to start drawing from
top - Top value to start drawing from
boxsize - Box size to draw
x_spacing - horizontal spacing to use
y_spacing - vertical spacing to use
depth - depth of the tree calculated
count - node count of the tree
node - current BinaryNode to process
Returns:
count plus this node

loadTree

public void loadTree(java.lang.String plan)
Load the tree based on a string that is in pre-order format.

Parameters:
plan - String containing the pre-order tree

loadTreeNodes

public BinaryTree loadTreeNodes(java.lang.StringBuffer plan)
Recursively load the nodes of the tree so they can be parsed later. Check if the plan still has data and get the first character. If its a - or | then this character is not a leaf node and parse the plan to find the left and right subtrees of this node (do this by recursively calling loadTreeNodes() using pre-order traversal). If the character is some other character, then this node is a leaf.

Parameters:
plan - String containing the current floor plan to parse
Returns:
BinaryTree containing the tree to work on

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Convert the tree to a string. Do so by doing an in-order traversal.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
See Also:
Object.toString()

drawFloorplan

public void drawFloorplan(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                          java.awt.Point topleft,
                          java.awt.Point bottomright)
Draw the floor plan. Setup the color and kick off the recursion.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to draw with
topleft - top left pixel coordinate to draw from
bottomright - bottom right pixel coordinate to draw with in

drawFloorplanNode

private void drawFloorplanNode(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                               BinaryNode node,
                               java.awt.Point topleft,
                               java.awt.Point bottomright)
Draw the individual parts of the floor plan. Determine the node's data and if its a control character like '-' or '|' then draw a line. If the node does not contain a control character, then label the area the node belongs to. The recursion uses pre-order traversal. During each pass, recalculate the box by dividing it in half and passing this new value along to the next iteration.

Parameters:
g - Graphics2D to draw with
node - Node to process
topleft - top left most coordinate to work with in
bottomright - bottom right most coordinate to work with in

getHalfCenter

private java.awt.Point getHalfCenter(java.awt.Point topleft,
                                     java.awt.Point bottomright)
Calculate the new center of the given box

Parameters:
topleft - Top left most point
bottomright - bottom right most point
Returns:
center of the given box coordinates
